node.title: Christina says a routine breast check saved her life. She's worried other women are missing out
node.alt: Christina Bullivant, a woman with dark hair, looks at the camera during an interview.
node.description: In parts of Australia hit by COVID-19 lockdowns, women could wait months for breast cancer screens. Doctors say they have a way to ease the backlog, but they need government support.Â
node.content:
["Christina Bullivant says a routine breast screen probably saved her life.", "The new mum was diagnosed with cancer in August 2020, after Sydney's initial COVID-19 lockdown had lifted.", "But when the New South Wales government closed breast screening clinics in Sydney's Delta outbreak, Ms Bullivant knew many women would miss out on the same chance she had.", "\"When the clinics closed this year it was really triggering for me and I just really feared for the women who wouldn't be able to make an appointment, who would miss their appointment and would then be diagnosed with a later-stage cancer,\" she told the ABC.", "Ms Bullivant started a petition for screening centres to reopen and quickly gained 30,000 signatures.", "", "
Breast screening centres have reopened after lockdowns, but demand is outstripping capacity.(ABC News: Louise Maher)
", "In late September, New South Wales began reopening clinics, but long backlogs remain in many places, and the service is prioritising women whose slots were cancelled during lockdowns.", "In Victoria, many women booking their first screening appointment could face a six-month wait.", "\"Right now, because of COVID-19, we are expecting there's a lot of women who are going to have a delayed diagnosis,\" said Nicole Borzillo, the senior project manager for the BreastScreen Initiative.", "The initiative is a proposal from the Australian General Practitioners Network and Australian Association of General Practitioners to improve breast cancer screening rates.", "Adelaide GP Rod Pearce, a director of the Australian General Practice Network, has spent years lobbying for changes to the BreastScreen program.", "He said GPs should be able to refer women to private radiology clinics for routine screening, a national screening database should be established, and GP and government software systems should be integrated.", "He also wants the government to\u00a0create a Medicare\u00a0item for comprehensive women's health checks so patients are eligible for rebates.", "
Push for boosted capacity
", "Dr Pearce said the COVID-19 backlog made it even more urgent to use private providers for extra screening capacity.", "\"Now's the time to put [in] that surge capacity. Diabetes, bowel cancer, breast cancer, any other program you can think of, general practice is the natural place for that surge capacity.\"", "", "
Rod Pearce and\u00a0Nicole Borzillo are pushing for governments to make screening services more accessible as a matter of urgency.(ABC News)
", "Dr Pearce and his team also said bringing GPs into the breast screening program would\u00a0raise screening rates.", "\"Australia has particularly low screening rates, we've never gotten above 59 per cent in the 32 years of BreastScreen,\" Ms Borzillo said.", "\"There have been multiple attempts and large amounts of funding used to develop programs to increase the participation rate, none have proven to be successful.", "\"The BreastScreen Initiative \u2026 offers a solution we believe will increase screening rates in Australia into the 90 per cent range.\"", "When asked by the ABC neither SA Health nor the federal Department of Health addressed\u00a0the main points of the\u00a0proposal \u2014 such as clearing the COVID-19 backlog and referring routine screens to private providers.", "They did say many GPs were already involved by discussing breast screening options and results with their patients.", "\"The Australian government is committed to increasing participation in the BreastScreen Australia program to 65 per cent\u00a0by 2025,\" the Department of Health said in a statement.", "\"The Australian government would welcome GPs promoting participation in the BreastScreen program, as an important avenue in lifting participation in the program.\"", "Australia is already experiencing a fall in cancer diagnoses due to COVID-19, with many doctors warning urgent action is needed.", "", "
What COVID-19 travel insurance doesn't cover you for(Emilia Terzon)
"]
